pros: “You're always going to have opportunities to grow within the company. You have a great way to gain experience through mentor-ships. Amazon has a very casual work environment.” Cons: “Amazon is a very frugal company, therefore no free lunches daily.
cons: Honestly I would say the only disadvantage of working for AMazon would be not having a social life. Because of the hours though you have off 3 days you still ..

pros: If you are a technical professional or just a tech enthusiast, AWS is the place to work (over the other silicon valley players Microsoft, Facebook, Twitter, Google, etc). AWS is the leader in cloud computing. Better products, better services, more innovation as a faster pace than our competitors and always keeping the customer #1 (Amazon leadership principle "Customer Obsession" is not just a tagline). Joining AWS means joining Amazon, yes. But it also means you benefit from the Amazon stock price if you are awarded RSUs, which most full time employees are. It takes 4 years for RSUs to vest 100%, but time moves fast in this organization. You will work with some of the smartest minds in the industry. Plenty of room for career growth in AWS and Amazon (you can transfer from one to the other).
cons: Each department in AWS runs like it's own company. Very much a start-up feel. Not a lot of structure (which can be good and bad). New hires should expect at least 6 to 12 months to be fully ramped (not even kidding). Performance reviews are annual, but you need to be "making a case" for yourself all year long as the opinions of your colleagues and peers is taken into consideration. The performance/productivity goals for recruiters (sourcers specifically) is unrealistic. Be ready for high volume recruiting if you're a technical sourcer. It's not enough to meet the bar, you have to raise it to be promoted. This means on top of an unrealistic hiring goals, you also have to take on several side projects. You'll easily work a 60 hour week for the first 2 years if you want to be promoted. As with all jobs, it's all about your manager. Make sure when you interview, you are scheduled to speak with the person you would report to and make sure you ask a lot of questions about their management style. That being said, lateral transfers are common, so if you don't like your manager, it's fairly easy to get transferred to another team. Base salary is below industry standards, but they try to make up for with the total compensation package that includes a signing bonus and the RSUs.

review_title: Love my team and the culture; hate the huge pay drop from year 4-5
job_title: Senior Technical Writer in Seattle, WA
pros: The company culture is fantstic. I love the teams that I work with. I really enjoy my work. I feel like I make a difference for millions of customers. I work with brilliant people. Everyone really wants to help each other and help the customers.
cons:
The RSU system is terrible. I'm a solid top performer that will take a huge pay cut during year 5. I've talked to my manager every year about my concerns. 

Here's what happens. When you're hired, you are granted stock for your first 4 years. After year 2, you earn stock that vests in year 5 based on performance. The company has a secret "total compensation target" for you. For example, assume that you receive the maximum allowed salary of $160,000. Assume that in year 1 and year 2, your total compensation (salary, signing bonus, and RSUs) is around $200,000. In year 3, 40% of your original stock grant vests, and that stock had 3 years of market growth. Year 3 total comp is $250,000. In year 4, the final 40% vests, and it had 4 years of market growth. Your year 4 total comp is $300,000. For year 5, your total comp drops back down to $200,000. When you talk to management, they tell you that you just had a large windfall and you should appreciate it, but expect only $200,000. When you talk to folks at Google, you find out that Google consistently pays more money for strong performers.

job_title: Tech Business Development in Seattle, WA
pros: They live and breath their leadership principles, which results in consistent growth and performance. It can be chaotic at time, but the formula for success is indisputable. Being a part of AWS is pretty incredible as so many companies have built their digital strategies on top of it.
cons: AWS, and Amazon at large, has a peculiar culture. Going to meetings where you review a 1, 2, or 6 page written document (a narrative) silently for the first 10-15 versus PowerPoint being an example. It's not for everyone. You need to have a lot of intellectual intensity, an ability to do things yourself, and embrace ambiguity and change. It's also incredibly hard to get hired, even if you are very experienced.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: benefits and good pay and fully equipped and amazing facilites
cons: high turn over, bad HR and management system, lack of openness, favoritism (Kind of leaning to racism), treat employee like crap

pros: Dental Insurance; $110 allowance for work shoes; will meet a lot of people; opportunity for promotion (albeit limited); generally clean and temperate work environment; five hour maximum work shift (you'll be ready to leave by the second hour I promise); most duties not overly strenuous or physically taxing
cons: (Not throwing stones, just calling a spade a spade) -- Very draconian attendance policy, resulting in a considerably high employee turnover rate. There is no such thing as an excused absence, with the possible exception being the death of a very close friend or relative. To put in perspective, if you have the flu and miss two days of work (each being a 10 hour work day), you are terminated; no exceptions. I have witnessed many many valuable employees let go for what would otherwise be excusable reasons at other companies. Secondly, they have entirely too many supervisors/managers. The old adage "too many chiefs and not enough Indians" could not be more relevant. Consequently, the left hand never seems to know what the right one is doing, and thus the sense of disorganization can be remarkably palpable. Although there are some supervisors/managers that are clearly competent with their position, the majority will leave you scratching your head wondering just how in the hell they landed a supervisory/management role. I recently overheard one associate joke that the qualifications for such roles must simply be breathing.  Furthermore, most of the job duties are by nature very redundant and boring, and the perception of time creeps at a snails pace. This is probably not a job that you will  "enjoy” per se, however, you won’t necessarily hate it either.  Last but not least, the spread of COVID is currently rampant there.  Their refusal to resume hazard pay is unspeakable, particularly for an already mega-wealthy company that has experienced an economic explosion due to the pandemic.

review_title: Amazon is a barcode generator, and you become a barcode.
pros: Decent pay if you don’t calculate the hourly rate.

I keep getting the runaround about answers to a few of my questions. “What is Amazon doing to ensure I don’t feel like another number in their system?” No answer.  I do apologize I am not robot and just accepted the job, but when you ask people to move across the country for a job opportunity and then say if you don’t finish a year you have to payback a prorated amount of your lump sum relocation assistance. That’s just unfair especially when LESS THAN 40% stay for 8 months. Amazon is using this position as a loan shark.

review_title: Do not join the Launch & Expansion related roles
pros: great pay, great processes in the last mile side. However life is horrible in the non tech related and expansion related roles.
cons:
The team does not have a spine to stand up to leadership(again this might be very specific to my case and team). A lot of the problem solving is by throwing people at the problem instead of redefining the process. So Amazon had setup a small team couple of years ago for launching new delivery stations across Europe and there were a lot of manual processes around building business cases, getting the things on ground rolled out etc. However AMZ is doing massive ramp up in EU(this is not confidential and you can figure out from the number of job posts in the region) and thus since the work has increased 10x, they are hiring 10x people for the same boring and mundane work which the then employees(so called team leads now) are working on. The team leads are young folks with zero idea about leadership and probably seeing power/authority for the first time. I wish the so long leads had spent some time in redefining the processes during their younger days in the organisation before going on a hiring spree. 

My colleagues are overly stressed(the pay is not that great for the stress), Amazon is a cult like environment. Everyone throws jargons around leadership principles and to be honest every situation can be retrofitted into any of these leadership principles. It is a very very top down culture which means the pressure trickles down from the top and gets harsher as it comes down. Amazon feels proud of its culture but it is a culture producing great workers but not loyal and innovative employees. 

I am already interviewing with organisations and will get out even before my stocks vest.
